Mike Trout's rookie season in 2012 was truly a remarkable one! He burst onto the scene and made an immediate impact, earning him numerous accolades and setting the tone for his future success. Here are some interesting facts about his rookie season:

**Call-up and Debut:**

* Trout was called up to the majors on July 8, 2012, from the Salt Lake Bees, the Triple-A affiliate of the Los Angeles Angels.
* He made his MLB debut on July 8, 2012, at 20 years and 243 days old, becoming the youngest player in the majors at the time.
* Trout started in center field and batted second in the lineup, going 1-for-3 with a run scored in a 6-1 loss to the Seattle Mariners.

**Rookie Season Statistics:**

* Played in 139 games, accumulating 559 at-bats
* Batted .326 with a .399 on-base percentage and .564 slugging percentage
* Hit 30 home runs, 27 doubles, and 7 triples
* Drove in 83 runs and scored 129 runs, leading the AL in the latter category
* Stole 49 bases, finishing second in the AL behind only the Oakland Athletics' Coco Crisp (51)

**Awards and Accolades:**

* Won the AL Rookie of the Year award unanimously, receiving all 28 first-place votes
* Finished second in the AL MVP voting, behind only Miguel Cabrera's historic Triple Crown season
* Named to the AL All-Star team, becoming the youngest position player to start in the Midsummer Classic since Ken Griffey Jr. in 1992

**Notable Achievements:**

* Became the first player in MLB history to hit 30 home runs, steal 40 bases, and score 125 runs in a single season
* Set an MLB rookie record with 10.7 WAR (Wins Above Replacement), surpassing the previous mark set by Mark McGwire in 1987
* Led the AL in stolen base percentage (92.5%) and ranked second in the majors in power-speed number (35.4)

**Impact on the Angels:**

* Helped the Angels win 89 games and finish third in the AL West, just missing the playoffs
* Formed a dynamic duo with Albert Pujols, who signed with the Angels in the offseason, and helped revitalize the team's offense

Trout's rookie season was a harbinger of things to come, showcasing his incredible all-around skills and setting the stage for his future success. He's since become one of the most dominant players in the game, and his rookie season remains one of the most impressive in MLB history.
